Introduction

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a clonal malignancy characterized by the accumulation of functionally incompetent, mature-appearing B lymphocytes in the peripheral blood, bone marrow, and lymphoid tissues.  It is a common form of leukemia in Western countries, occurring primarily in older adults.

Pathogenesis



CLL develops in a stepwise process involving:



  • Monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis:  Various factors (eg, antigenic stimulation, mutations in genes that can disrupt cell cycle regulation [eg, TP53], upregulation of antiapoptotic proteins [eg, BCL2]) lead to the unregulated proliferation of a single mature B lymphocyte.  This population of monoclonal B lymphocytes can be detected in the peripheral blood but is functionally incompetent (ie, unable to mount an appropriate immune response to an infection).  Patients are asymptomatic and have no other clinical findings at this stage.  It is estimated that monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis is present in ~10% of people age >60.
  • Progression to CLL:  Due to additional genetic mutations (eg, 13q deletion) or tumor microenvironment interactions (which provide signals enhancing survival of the abnormal cells), patients with monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis can progress to CLL, defined as â‰¥5000 cells/ÂµL of monoclonal B lymphocytes.  Most patients remain asymptomatic until lymphocyte accumulation in various tissues (eg, bone marrow, lymph nodes) causes symptoms (eg, anemia, neutropenia, lymphadenopathy) with disease progression.


CLL is often associated with significant immune dysfunction, affecting both humoral and cell-mediated immunity:



  • Humoral immunity:  Monoclonal B lymphocytes can interfere with normal immunoglobulin production.

    • Hypogammaglobulinemia:  This occurs in approximately two-thirds of patients during the course of disease.  In addition, patients do not mount an adequate immune response to vaccinations, increasing the risk for vaccine-preventable disease.
    • Autoantibody production:  Interactions between monoclonal B lymphocytes and normal B lymphocytes can result in production of IgG autoantibodies, resulting in autoimmune hemolytic anemia and/or immune thrombocytopenia.
  • Cell-mediated immunity:  CLL can downregulate T-cell function.


CLL is primarily a disease of older adults (median age at diagnosis: 70), and there is an increased risk among first-degree family members with CLL.

Clinical presentation



Patients with CLL are often asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally.  When symptomatic, patients can present with:



  • Lymphadenopathy:  Presentation is usually painless and firm and located along the cervical, supraclavicular, and/or axillary region.
  • Splenomegaly and/or hepatomegaly.
  • Cytopenias (eg, due to disrupted hematopoiesis, autoimmune antibody production):  Symptoms include fatigue and pallor due to anemia and/or bruising and bleeding complications from thrombocytopenia.
  • Infections:  Sinopulmonary infections due to hypogammaglobulinemia are most common.


Less commonly, patients may have B-symptoms (eg, unexplained fever >38 C [100.4 F] for 3 consecutive days, drenching night sweats, weight loss >10% of body weight over 6 months).  Some patients may have exaggerated reactions to insect bites, which may be related to immune dysregulation and abnormal cytokine production in CLL.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for CLL includes other causes of absolute lymphocytosis, including:



  • Reactive lymphocytosis:  can occur due to infection with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) or cytomegalovirus (CMV).  These conditions can also present with lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly.  However, peripheral smear shows atypical lymphocytes (
    image 1
    ) (not monoclonal B lymphocytes), and immunophenotyping is characteristic of a polyclonal lymphocyte population.  In addition, reactive lymphocytosis is usually transient and resolves with the underlying infection, unlike CLL.
  • Other lymphoid malignancies (eg, hairy cell leukemia (
    image 2
    ), mantle cell lymphoma) may present with elevated lymphocyte counts.  Immunophenotyping helps differentiate these disorders by identification of cell surface markers.

Diagnosis



Laboratory evaluation in a patient with CLL typically shows:



  • Complete blood count:  This often includes dramatically elevated leukocyte count (often >100,000/mm3), normocytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Peripheral smear:  Characteristic findings include an abundance of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes, some of which may have a classic "smudged" appearance due to increased fragility that causes breakage during smear preparation (
    image 3
    ).


The diagnosis of CLL requires:



  • Absolute lymphocyte count â‰¥5000/mm3 for at least 3 months
  • A population of leukocytes with B-cell surface markers (eg, CD19, CD20, CD23) and CD5 (a T-cell surface marker expressed on CLL cells)
  • Expression of low levels of surface immunoglobulins that contain only kappa or lambda light chains, confirming monclonality (as opposed to a mixture of both kappa and lambda light chains, suggesting polyclonality)


Bone marrow evaluation is generally not required but may be considered if the diagnosis is unclear, revealing infiltration by CLL cells.  Staging for CLL is based on clinical findings that correlate with the degree of tumor burden, which predicts overall risk and disease prognosis.  Lymphocytosis alone represents early-stage disease (ie, low tumor burden and low risk/favorable prognosis).  As CLL progresses, leukemic cells infiltrate other organs (eg, spleen, liver) and impair hematopoiesis, causing organomegaly, anemia, and/or thrombocytopenia.  These findings reflect high-stage disease and poorer prognosis.

Management



The management strategy for CLL depends on the presence of symptoms:



  • Asymptomatic CLL:  Because there is no improvement in long-term survival with early therapy, patients with low-stage, asymptomatic disease are closely monitored with routine laboratory evaluation.  Though rare, spontaneous regressions can occur.
  • Symptomatic CLL (ie, "active disease"):  For patients with advanced-stage disease who develop symptoms (eg, progressive bone marrow failure causing cytopenias, lymphadenopathy/splenomegaly, B symptoms), treatment may be initiated to improve symptoms and halt disease progression (CLL is generally not curable with current therapy).  The choice of first-line therapy depends on various factors (eg, patient age, tumor features) and may include:
    • Targeted therapy:  Specific proteins within B lymphocytes (eg, Bruton tyrosine kinase [BTK], phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase [PI3K]) can be targeted in B cell malignancies like CLL.  BTK and PI3K are both involved in key intracellular signaling processes that affect growth and survival of mature B cells and are expressed in malignant B cells.  Incorporation of BTK inhibitors (eg, ibrutinib) and PI3K inhibitors (eg, idelalisib) have improved survival rates in CLL.  Because BCL-2 is often overexpressed in CLL, it can also be targeted with BCL-2 inhibitors (eg, venetoclax).
    • Chemotherapy:  These agents include fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab (a monoclonal antibody against the CD20 antigen).


Complications associated with CLL may require supportive care (eg, prophylactic antibiotics for opportunistic infections, aggressive intravenous hydration for tumor lysis syndrome (

figure 1
)).

Prognosis



The prognosis for CLL is favorable, though variable, with a median survival of 10 years from diagnosis.  In general, patients with a higher stage, which correlates with total disease burden, have a worse prognosis.  In addition, certain genetic mutations (eg, TP53 mutations, del[17p]) are associated with a worse prognosis.  Treatment can induce remission and control disease for several years.



Beyond disease progression, other common complications in CLL include systemic infections (contributed by immune dysfunction related to CLL along with adverse effects of treatment) and eventual transformation to a more aggressive lymphoma (Richter syndrome).

Summary



Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a clonal malignancy characterized by the accumulation of functionally incompetent, mature-appearing B lymphocytes in the peripheral blood, bone marrow, and lymphoid tissues (
